facts.text: Chinese attacked the northern border of India on the 8th September, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: As is well-known, after the Chinese attacked the northern border of India on the 8th September, 1962, the President issued a Proclamation under Art. 352 of the Constitution on the 26th October, 1962.

facts.text: President issued a Proclamation under Art. 352 declaring grave emergency on 26th October, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: the President issued a Proclamation under Art. 352 of the Constitution on the 26th October, 1962. This proclamation declared that a grave emergency existed which posed a threat to the security of India.

facts.text: President promulgated an Ordinance on 26th October, 1962, subsequently modified by Ordinance No. 6 on 3rd November, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, an Ordinance was promulgated by the President. This Ordinance was subsequently modified by Ordinance No. 6 of 1962 on the 3rd of November, 1962.

facts.text: President issued Order under Art. 359 suspending rights under Articles 21 and 22 on 26th October, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The President also issued an Order under Art. 359 suspending the rights of citizens to move any court for the enforcement of the rights conferred by Articles 21 and 22 during the pendency of the emergency proclamation.

facts.text: Rules under Defence of India Act published on 26th October, 1962; Rule 30 modified on 6th December, 1962; Rule 30-A added.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th October, 1962, the Rules framed by the Central Government under the Defence of India Act hereinafter called the Rules were published. Rule 30 of the Rules as originally framed was subsequently modified on the 6th December, 1962 and Rule 30-A was added.

facts.text: Defence of India Act passed on 12th December, 1962, repealing earlier Ordinances but continuing Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Later, an Act was passed on the 12th December, 1962, and s. 48(1) of this Act provided for the repeal of the earlier Ordinances. Even so, s. 48(2) provided for the continuance of the Rules framed under the Ordinances

facts.text: Mr. Mukerjee, Administrator of Tripura, directed detention of 68 persons under Rule 30(1)(b).

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Mr. Mukerjee who was the Administrator of the Union Territory of Tripura -at the relevant time, considered the material placed before him as such Administrator and was satisfied that a group of Communists had been agitating amongst the tribals residing in the area and inciting them against the Government, and he came to the conclusion that their activities were likely to endanger the security of the State. Acting on this view, he directed that 68 persons should be detained under Rule 30(1)(b) and passed appropriate orders in that behalf.

facts.text: 45 out of 68 detained persons were released by Mr. Mukerjee.

anchor.surface_text: Later, he was satisfied that 45 out of these 68 persons need not be detained any longer and so, he ordered their release from time to time. That left 23 persons under detention

facts.text: 12 out of 23 detained persons filed Habeas Corpus Petitions under Art. 226 before Judicial Commissioner of Tripura.

anchor.surface_text: 12 out of these 23 persons moved the Judicial Commissioner of Tripura under Art. 226 of the Constitution and prayed that the orders of detention under which they continued to be detained at the time of their petitions were illegal and should be set aside and they should be ordered to be released forthwith.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner dismissed the Habeas Corpus petitions on January 18, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1964, of the Judicial Commissioners Court for Tripura in Criminal Misc. Habeas Corpus Petitions Nos. 15, 20, 25, 26 and 28 of 1963, and Habeas Corpus Petitions Nos. 24 and 27 of 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for Criminal Appeals Nos. 87-91, 106 and 107 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal Nos. 87-91 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 18, 1964, of the Judicial Commissioners Court for Tripura in Criminal Misc. Habeas Corpus Petitions Nos. 15, 20, 25, 26 and 28 of 1963, and Habeas Corpus Petitions Nos. 24 and 27 of 1963.

facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 43,42,40,41,65,80 of 1964 filed under Art. 32 for remaining 11 detenues.

anchor.surface_text: AND Writ Petitions Nos. 43, 42, 40, 41, 65 and 80 of 1964. Petition Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of the fundamental rights.

facts.text: Biren Dutta detained on 25th December, 1962; order served on him.

anchor.surface_text: We would, therefore, refer to the facts relevant to the case of the detenu Biren Dutta. Biren Dutta was detained on the 25th December, 1962, and an order issued in that behalf was duly served on him.

facts.text: Biren Dutta transferred to Hazaribagh Jail on 26th December, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th December, 1962, he was transferred to the Hazaribagh Jail.

facts.text: Respondent claims review of Biren Dutta's case on 15th February, 1963 under Rule 30A(8), decided to continue detention.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case is that on the 15th February, 1963, the case of Biren Dutta was reviewed under R. 30A(8) and it was decided to continue his deten- tion.

facts.text: Petitioner Biren Dutta contended no review order under R. 30A(8) passed or communicated.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, Biren Duttas contention before the Judicial Commissioner was that an order of review had not been passed as required by R. 30A(8) and had not been communicated to him.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner found decision to continue detention reduced to writing based on original file produced.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner has negatived the contentions thus raised by the detenu. He has found that the decision to continue the detenus detention reached by the respondent under R. 30A(8) had in fact been reduced to writing, and in support of this contention, he has referred to the fact that the original file containing a record of the decision had been produced on behalf of the respondent before the Judicial Commissioner

facts.text: Supreme Court passed interim order on 6th May, 1964 directing production of original files and affidavit.

anchor.surface_text: When these matters were argued before this Court on the 6th May, 1964, an interim order was passed directing that the Chief Secretary to the Tripura Administration should forthwith transmit to this Court the original files in respect of the detenues concerned and that the Minister, or the Secretary or the Administrator who reviewed the cases of the detenues and had arrived at a decision that their detention should be continued, should file an affidavit in this Court on or before the 8th June, 1964

facts.text: Original files produced before Supreme Court; Solicitor-General allowed inspection.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the original files have been produced before us and additional affidavits have been filed. The learned Solicitor-General fairly conceded that he would allow Mr. Garg for the appellants an opportunity to inspect the files inasmuch as he was not going to raise any question of privilege in respect of them.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no written record of decision to continue detention under R. 30A(8) for the detenues.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the decision to continue the detention of the detenues which, it is urged on behalf of the respondent, was reached by him under R. 30A(8), has not been recorded in writing as required by the said Rule and there is no other evidence on record to show that such a decision had then been reached and reduced to writing.

facts.text: On 15th February, 1963, order cancelled detention of some listed detenues but silent on others.

anchor.surface_text: The first occasion on which the respondent claims to have reviewed the cases of the detenues before us was on the 15th February, 1963. On that date, he made the following order- On review of the detention order in respect of all detenus CC decided to cancel detention orders in respect of detenues at S. No. 1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 12 and 13.

facts.text: Supreme Court held order of 15th February, 1963 does not show decision to continue detention of these detenues.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the memorandum in question can be reasonably said to include a decision that the continuance of the detention of the detenues before us was thought to be necessary by the appropriate authority after the expiry of the period of six months.

facts.text: On 3rd July, 1963, order released 25 detenues recommended by Superintendent of Police; these detenues not included.

anchor.surface_text: Then as to the next order passed on the 3rd July, 1963, the position is still worse. ... These detenues were 25 in number. ... It is common ground that the detenues before us were not included in the said list of 25 detenues

facts.text: Supreme Court held no compliance with R. 30A(8); continuance of detention invalid.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion necessarily means that the requirement of R. 30A(8) has not been complied with and that inevitably makes the continuance of the detention of the detenues before invalid in law.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on July 23, 1964 by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J.

anchor.surface_text: July 23, 1964, The Judgment of the Court was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR C. J.-These Criminal Appeals and Writ Petitions have been placed for hearing together in a group because they raise common questions of law.
Petition Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of the fundamental rights.
12 out of these 23 persons moved the Judicial Commissioner of Tripura under Art. 226 of the Constitution

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether the orders passed under Rule 30(1)(b) and the record of the decision reached under Rule 30A(8) should comply with Article 166 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think it necessary to consider the question as to whether the orders passed under R. 30 1   b  and the record of the decision reached under R.30A 8  should comply with Art. 166 of the Constitution or number.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as not necessary for disposal of the cases.

holdings.text: It is unnecessary to decide whether the decision recorded under Rule 30A(8) should be communicated to the detenu.

anchor.surface_text: It also appears to us to be unnecessary to decide in the present group of cases whether the decision recorded under R. 30A  8  should be communicated to the detenu.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue avoided as not necessary for disposal of the cases.

holdings.text: Rule 30A(8) requires that the decision to continue detention be recorded in writing.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the decision to continue the detention of the detenues which, it is urged on behalf of the respondent, was reached by him under R. 30A 8 , has not been recorded in writing as required by the said Rule

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground between parties and scheme of rules; conceded by Solicitor-General.

holdings.text: There is no written record or other evidence of a decision under Rule 30A(8) to continue the detention of these detenues.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the decision to continue the detention of the detenues which, it is urged on behalf of the respondent, was reached by him under R. 30A(8), has not been recorded in writing as required by the said Rule and there is no other evidence on record to show that such a decision had then been reached and reduced to writing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inspection of original files shows no minutes recording decision for these specific detenues.

holdings.text: The order dated 15th February 1963 does not record or imply a decision to continue detention of these specific detenues.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the memorandum in question can be reasonably said to include a decision that the continuance of the detention of the detenues before us was thought to be necessary by the appropriate authority after the expiry of the period of six months.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction of the order; it only specifies cancellations, no affirmative continuation for others; timing before six months expiry.

holdings.text: The order dated 3rd July 1963 does not record a decision under Rule 30A(8) to continue detention of these detenues.

anchor.surface_text: Then as to the next order passed on the 3rd July, 1963, the position is still worse. ... These detenues were 25 in number. ... It is common ground that the detenues before us were not included in the said list of 25 detenues

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order concerns only 25 specific detenues recommended for release; these petitioners not included.

holdings.text: Non-compliance with the writing requirement of Rule 30A(8) renders the continuance of detention invalid.

anchor.surface_text: This conclusion necessarily means that the requirement of R. 30A(8) has not been complied with and that inevitably makes the continuance of the detention of the detenues before invalid in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule mandates review decision; absence invalidates post-six-month detention.

holdings.text: Subsequent reviews after the initial six-month period do not validate prior illegal continuance of detention.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Initial compliance required; gap creates illegality not cured retrospectively.

holdings.text: The appropriate authority exercising power under Rule 30A(8) should record its decision clearly and unambiguously.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberty at stake demands clarity in records affecting detention.

holdings.text: Even if not legally required, it is desirable to communicate the Rule 30A(8) decision to the detenu.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fairness and justice require communication for transparency in preventive detention.

edges.explanation: Holding directly responds to the issue by stating it is not necessary to decide compliance of orders under R. 30(1)(b) with Art. 166

anchor.surface_text: We do not think it necessary to consider the question as to whether the orders passed under R. 30 1   b  and the record of the decision reached under R.30A 8  should comply with Art. 166 of the Constitution or number.
It also appears to us to be unnecessary to decide in the present group of cases whether the decision recorded under R. 30A  8  should be communicated to the detenu.

We are satisfied that the decision to continue the detention of the detenues which, it is urged on behalf of the respondent, was reached by him under R. 30A 8 , has not been recorded in writing as required by the said Rule

This companyclusion necessarily means that the requirement of R. 30A 8 has number been companyplied with and that inevitably makes the companytinuance of the detention of the detenues before invalid in law.

We are satisfied that the decision to continue the detention of the detenues which, it is urged on behalf of the respondent, was reached by him under R. 30A(8), has not been recorded in writing as required by the said Rule and there is no other evidence on record to show that such a decision had then been reached and reduced to writing.

This companyclusion necessarily means that the requirement of R. 30A 8 has number been companyplied with and that inevitably makes the companytinuance of the detention of the detenues before invalid in law.

We are unable to hold that the memorandum in question can be reasonably said to include a decision that the continuance of the detention of the detenues before us was thought to be necessary by the appropriate authority after the expiry of the period of six months.

This companyclusion necessarily means that the requirement of R. 30A 8 has number been companyplied with and that inevitably makes the companytinuance of the detention of the detenues before invalid in law.

This companyclusion necessarily means that the requirement of R. 30A 8 has number been companyplied with and that inevitably makes the companytinuance of the detention of the detenues before invalid in law.
This conclusion necessarily means that the requirement of R. 30A(8) has not been complied with and that inevitably makes the continuance of the detention of the detenues before invalid in law.
